title: AB 289
content: The State of California enacts the following. The State of California enacts the Legislative Employee Whistleblower Protection Act, allowing legislative employees to report ethical violations without fear of retribution. It defines "legislative employee" as someone employed by the Legislature, and "protected disclosure" as filing a complaint with the Joint Legislative Ethics Committee or the Senate Committee on Legislative Ethics. The Legislative Employee Whistleblower Protection Act in California prohibits the use of official authority to intimidate or interfere with a legislative employee's right to make a protected disclosure. The Act allows for reporting of ethical violations to various committees and an ethics ombudsperson designated by the Legislature. The Legislative Employee Whistleblower Protection Act in California prohibits intimidation or interference with a legislative employee's right to make a protected disclosure. Violators may face fines up to $10,000 and one year in jail, as well as civil liability for damages. The Act does not allow disclosure of prohibited information and allows supervisors to take personnel actions based on separate evidence. The Legislative Employee Whistleblower Protection Act in California allows employees to file complaints for reprisal or retaliation for protected disclosures. Violators may face fines and jail time, with immunity for legislators. Former employees are also protected under this act. The Legislative Employee Whistleblower Protection Act in California allows for civil action against individuals engaging in reprisal or retaliation against legislative employees for protected disclosures. The burden of proof shifts to the offending party to show legitimate reasons for their actions once retaliation is proven. Punitive damages may be awarded for malicious acts, with the injured party entitled to attorney's fees. The Legislative Employee Whistleblower Protection Act in California allows for civil action against individuals engaging in reprisal or retaliation against legislative employees for protected disclosures. A legislative employee is not required to file a complaint before bringing an action for civil damages. Supervisors can take personnel actions based on separate evidence. The definition of "legislative employee" includes former employees if the complaint is filed within one year of the improper act. This article does not diminish the rights of legislative employees under any other law. SEC. 2. This act does not require reimbursement under the California Constitution as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
